What is Theme Park Studio and who would want it?

Theme Park Studio is a sandbox theme park building simulator game with no limits. You can build as much as you want however you want. Once you figure out how the program works, it is really fun and you can make gorgeous things. Gone are the days of being stuck to a stupid grid, forcing strict limitations on where you can put stuff. Also gone are the days where you are stuck with the limited content that the devs provide. Importing new content is easy, and the program is specifically designed for no fuss custom importing of 3d objects, terrain brushes, scenery, textures etc... You can even create and customize your own skyboxes.

So you should purchase if:
*You want to help out and support some awesome devs who are open, honest, and passionate about their game
*You love making pretty things and being creative
*You want to get involved in the already awesome growing community and start contributing

You should not purchase if:
*You are looking for the next Roller Coaster Tycoon game. This is a sandbox pure and simple. There is no money management or scenarios of any kind. Although there is a strong possibility that it may be added in the future.
*You are a party pooper or a hater
*You are looking for a 100% perfect feature complete product. It's early access. Do bear that in mind and when they say Please only purchase if you are interested in being involved in the ongoing development of this exciting project" They aren't kidding.

I will continue to update this as development continues.

I always used to play RCT3 (probably like everyone else). And I have to say this game is very well structured. I will give you a list comparing this game to RCT3 so you can have a better understanding of what each game brings to the table SO FAR. I say so far because this game is still in development, and it could change. Here is my opinion:

>>>>Theme Park Studio vs RCT3<<<<
GRAPHICS:
Theme park studio wins this one, it has way better graphics, and antialising makes the game look a lot better as well (if you have the graphics card for it). The water reflections look great, and the coaster detail is a lot better. HD!

GAMEPLAY:
RCT3 wins. RCT feels like an actual amusement park game, because it has a lot of features like the peeps, stands, money, financing, etc. This kind of stuff made you feel like you were managing your own theme park. Theme Park Studio is still in development, so they might add some more features like this soon. It just feels like more of a sandbox than an actual theme park game.

COASTER EDITING:
Theme park studio is by far the best editor I have come across. There are so many possibilities for coasters, you can truly make it your own.  Each track segment can be edited to your liking, so you can truly make any coaster you have in mind. It is also very easy to use, with some pre-loaded segments like a cobra roll or a loop. When it comes to flexibility, TPS wins.

SOUNDS:
Although I have big expectations for TPS to have a great sound library, currently i would say RCT has better sounds. They are more consistent, and they have better variety.  For example, on the megacoaster, the lift chain sound on TPS does not make much sense at all. Also, there is no fading so sounds seem to come out of nowhere sometimes. I do expect them to have better sounds in the future though.

USER INTERFACE:
I'm going to be honest, the TPS user interface takes some getting used to. The RCT user interface in my opinion is more understandable, and it's easier to use. TPS just kind of seems all over the place.  Maybe they will update this soon, i just find it easier to play RCT instead of TPS. But then again, it's also about personal preference.

That should cover most of the basic categories.  In my opinion, I prefer Theme Park Studio over roller coaster tycoon.  TPS is still on the early versions, and it has A LOT going for it once they start adding people, and adding more management features. Don't get me wrong, I will always like rct, but tps seems like the next step up.  That is all! I hope this helps some of you clear up some differences.

Have a great day ! Dated: January 15th, 2015

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have been trying tp keep up wih this game to see how the game is progressing through its development stages and how the development team has been responding to the users and the issues they have been having while trying to run the software. I hope this review helps other make a educated decision on whether the game is worth purchasing. I am happy to report the following observations and my take on the game, even after playing for hours.

TPS is a must have for any hardcore fan of the Theme Park/Rollercoaster genre. Not only does the game provide a very strong studio editor for creating your own customized realistic Park, it provides the user with a good educational value of roller coaster physics and 3D edited flat rides. You are only limited in this game by your own imagination.

At first glance, the UI looks intimidating,  but the staff at Pantera Entertainment have helped users overcome that obstacle very quickly by providing a strong background of how to use documentation included in the game along with a host of how to videos covering everything from building coasters to landscaping your own park. With that said, understanding the UI can quickly become second nature and easily managed after a few times of use. The incorporated Steam Worshop also makes it easy to import custom scenery and rides into the game without leaving the game interface.

The coaster builder will set well with RCT3 fans, as it employees some of the same techniques while adding the ability to easily manipulate the control of creating banked turns and twisted track with the help of track nodes, something that RCTW seems to also be incorporating with their spline based track editor.  The track editor also has more features than RCT3 and without a doubt is better suited towards this game giving the user the ability to manipulate the track in every way possible.

Now with all that said, everyone needs to understand that this software is still in the early access program phase and that they may and probally will encounter bugs and crashes due to their computer hardware conflicts and not having updated drivers. But with that thought, I must also say from strong observation, that the development team is doing an excellent job of addressing those issues if the users will report the problems they are having in the forum threads.

Most of the people who are complaining and rating bad reviews are those who won't give the team the time to work out the bugs and put out a completed product that is highly polished. I have been able to play the game on a Windows 7 machine that was not build as a high end gaming outfit, very sucessfully. And although I have encourted a crash or two, I can clearly see the power that this game has that can't be found in other theme park builder games on the market.

Although the game does not concentrate on the financial management of your park, it still ranks among the top best in Theme Park building games to have for fanatics and should be included in anyone's library who enjoyed RCT3 and/or No Limits Roller Coaster Simulation and for those who are interested in creating a very realistic Theme Park.

On a scale from 1 to 5, the game gets 4.5 stars for the power that it has to create any realistic park and for the backup support the team has put into the game and continues to provide for the fan base it has.  If it was not for the fact that the game is still development mode, it would carry 5 stars all the way. Bottom line, this game is highly recommended.

So the only question to gamers who are interested in this game, is whether they want to participate in the early access build or whether they want to wait until the game is completely finished. I hope this review helps those who are on the fence deciding on what the game provides and has to offer in the form of Theme Park Simulation building.

I have now been working with Theme Park Studio for a really long time and I have to tell you, it is without a doubt the BEST theme park creation software out there. No other software short of a 3D animation powerhouse like Maya or Modo can do what TPS can.

It's obvious that the creator of this software has put sweat, blood and tears into this software and it shows. The coasters are amazing, fun to build and incredible to ride. It's amazing how TPS just automatically adds and adjusts the coaster's supports in response to lifting or lowering track pieces. Node editing is intuitive and fun. You can really get in there and make it perfect by using the node editor and editing by the numbers. It's insanely easy to add batwings, loops, corkscrews and plenty of other amazing inversions and specialty pieces. Lastly, I love how TPS can auto-close the coaster track. You can color or texture anything anyway you want. It has plenty of coaster types (all the major ones), like winged, steel, inverted, wood, mine train, etc) and you can customize the coaster any way you want. Finally, you can add custom scenery to your parks. I've added rocks, buildings and tunnels for the coasters to go by and through - amazing!

The path editing is amazing. I love how terrain automatically adjusts itself when you raise or lower a path. It's also great that the path's struts, bridges, etc all adjust themselves in realtime. You can put foliage, sidewalks and other things inside and outside paths. You can create traffic circles, junctions and more. Very, very complete path editor.

The flat rides that come with it are so real! The physics are spot on and you can ride all of them. With Bumper Cars and Boats coming - and Go Karts! - I just think Theme Park Studio is one hell of a good deal and simply cannot be beat in the theme park creation arena.

It has particles (think fireworks, snow, fire, etc) and full editing and creation of just about anything (you can make buildings, rides, etc).

You can enter the park and it has peeps that ride the rides with you (kids and adults). There is so much to this software that it's almost impossible to mention everything it can do. If it's THIS amazing in early access, I can't imagine how good it will be when fully released!

No doubt about it - after logging in tons of hours with Theme Park Studio, i've never been so excited about a piece of software. It just keeps getting better and better.

- Karmacomposer

Theme Park Studio is a mix between roller coaster tycoon sandbox and no limits.   All three titles do some things better than the other and each has strengths and weaknesses when compared, but overall I like Theme Park Studio best because it offers the most customization without spending a lot of time on a single project and the visual quality competes with either of the other products.   I don't have to use a 3d modeling program, everything I build can be done directly from in the game or using workshop items.  I do use .jpg image textures from the internet however.   The thing to keep in mind is this is not Roller Coaster Tycoon or No Limits, it's a different game from a different developer and what it does it does well.  Much more than just coasters there is also custom animations, textures, lighting, landscapes, particles, sounds, and so much more.

This is like a set of sandbox tools you would find in roller coaster tycoon with no goals or money to worry about, just build your park the way you want it.   The coaster and path tools are pretty similiar to Roller Coaster Tycoon and were reworked a few phases ago to make them much easier to use, now it's simply point and click to build coasters and paths or you can also use the drawing tool to draw a path with the mouse.   For advanced players there are tons of advanced options and controls available to customize just about everything.   They even added multi-core support in the last phase which tripled my FPS.   In the videos below you can see just how far you can take the customizations.

The game has come a long way since the early phases and soon we will get peeps walking around, 1st person camera mode on rides, many more flat rides all in the final phase.   Since all the rides are physic based and not scripted these are going to be amazing in first person mode.   I'll let me videos speak to the quality of Theme Park Studio, each park you build will get better and faster.   It takes me longer to record videos than build parks now. First of all, this game is early acces. Don't expect this game to be completed. I'm making this review based on things I've tried for myself.

Theme park studio is a great tool for people who want to Design their own theme park. Yes I said design. This game is all about designing a theme park. Not about running one. That means that in TPS (Theme Park Studio) you don't have to care about money. As I said this is a game to design your own themepark. In TPS you will be able to install/make custom content (Scenery, Rides, Textures, Height maps and much more). Using this custom content you (almost) have no limitations to your imagination. A great feature that makes this game different from other theme park related games is the fact that you're able to work with or without a grid. This allows for more natural looking parks instead of having everything line up with each other.

Let's talk about some stuff I really like about this game (Those are more opinion based).
The path system in this game is nice because you're able to make curved paths without having to download custom content. This also brings some problems (Those things might be fixed in future updates). Building a Y formed path may be hard sometimes. Currently (18-3-2014) you've got to be very creative to come up with solution to prevent strange side walks. But I'm sure this will be fixed.
Graphics are something I just love about this game. Having the ability to use high poly models without to much problems really is a thing I like. Also textures look really nice because of normal mapping (Mini 3D details that aren't actually 3D).

After all I really like this game and I'm excited to see what Pantera will bring us in upcoming updates!

First off, this is an early access beta. I bought it because it's Oculus Rift DK2 compatible. Despite my rating, I say do not buy it yet unless you're interested in providing feedback for the beta and don't mind dealing with an incomplete and very buggy game. It's got issues, big ones.

It's extremely unstable. It's crashed several times and I had to verify file integrity twice because crashes corrupted the defaut demo parks. Took me the better part of an hour and a half to get it to work well enough to test out one of the coasters. I downloaded the coaster of the month from the Workshop for this because there isn't much to the demo parks that come with it by default.

It loads slow as well and has a tendency to get to the edge of crashing during a load. I've found the best thing to do is sit back and not touch anything while it's loading. A few of the windows and taskbars will go white while it's loading, but after a few moments it finishes and everything ran fine for the most part.

My crashes were mostly related to loading errors and Alt-Tab, the game does not like Alt-Tab and has a nasty tendency to freeze if you do. Once everything was loaded it didn't give me any trouble so far, but still remember to save often if you're building something because I wouldn't trust it to not crash while I was building after a while right now.

The only rides you can test are the roller coasters. Hoping that will change in the future. The coasters are cool, but it'd be nice to have a go at anything in the park you can build, including the flat rides. Still worth it for only the coasters, but I'm hoping there will be more to it than that later on.

I got stuck a couple of times in some of the scenery when walking about. Not a huge deal, just hit the ticket icon to teleport back to the entrance. Not really a big problem, but it does happen on occasion.

It also very badly needs a mouselook button. A lot of the rides and scenery is very tall, but as far as I can tell you can only look about at ground level and can't look up at anything when roaming the park in first person.

DK2 support needs work. The view doesn't twist or turn with the ride and simply remains level while rising and falling with the height of the ride and never twiting or inverting with the track. Also, positional tracking for leaning forward and back is reversed, leaning forward makes the player move back rather than forward. That might work for a very basic coaster with no banks or loops, but it doesn't cut it for anything complex enough to be fun to ride in VR.

Hopefully Oculus Rift support will be expanded in the future to include wandering about the park itself and trying the other rides as well. Right now it's limited to testing out the coasters only.

Why recommend it then?

Well, this has huge potential. The Workshop support means that there will be hundreds if not thousands of coasters to play with in the future. People can get really creative with this and it's sure to impress, especially if there's more to it than just riding coasters. It also gives me a solid framerate and no judder on my system, I've got a very nice PC 7970 and 3770k, but I can crank everything to max and have it run smooth in VR, which is very nice. A comparatively weak system should be able to run this at lower graphics settings in VR without too much trouble and it still won't look bad either.

No management. There are no resources or management happening. It's a creative toy that doesn't need to be managed to enjoy. The focus here seems to be about building and experiencing the rides, not worrying about customer happiness, whether there are enough bathrooms, or the price of hot dogs.  I like games that do that sort of thing, but it's nice to have something like this that is a purly creative tool that can be experienced and shared.

Despite the flaws of the Oculus support, it's still a lot of fun to ride the coasters. The camera desperatly needs to be fixed, there are demos that far outclass what this can currently do because of this issue, but when that's fixed it will be a worthy investment due to what can be accomplished with this game.

It's also pretty, not amazing or anything, but the graphics look good for a sim sanbox type game. They run well in VR and look good in the DK2 HMD.

I recommend this game because it's got huge potential, especially for those with VR. It's not there yet and if you may be better off waiting until the game is further along before picking it up. It's an early Beta though, so it's issues are not unexpected, though it is a bit more unstable than I'd like and that alone almost got it a no" for now.

The creative freedom it allows for

Ok so the game at the moment has been said many times that this is an alpha and anyone who has paid straight up not looking into the info stated are the people moaning that there is no coaster building yet...  all I can say to that is do some research and stick to updates of the game then you wouldn't run into these problems, I've been following the project since day one and have been amazed with how much Pantera has taken on board from the input they have had from the community so they clearly care about their fanbase unlike other devs these days which is a bonus for them and us.

Onto the actual game, many people have come into this game thinking it is RCT3 and that is understandable but this is not as this game tool is much more than that. This game has so much potential to be the greatest theme park game ever created, currently it is still in Alpha so don't expect every feature yet but once we get to that full release I can not see this game failing, the community have already started making Custom scenery to add to the game which is amazing for a title what is not even fully released yet, just shows how well intagrated and open the games own tools are. Ok onto the games controls, they work perfectly in my opinion and you can even go upside down with the camera if you truly wanted to.

How does the games building tool work in the game ? Well I find the building work on this game to be great, the benefit aswell is you can turn off grid lock mode and just free roam your object anywhere, any direction or even tilt the object if you require it. I think that is truly incredible and just shows in one simple task of the games features how powerful their game tool is already and THIS IS JUST ALPHA at the moment so how can you possibly grumble at it. Paths can be either simple or complicated, currently the paths are created freely so you can place the paths where you want and curve and get really nice arc shaped paths, you can even bend the paths and raise or lower them if you must. One of the main features in this game is the resize option which allows me to resize any object if i feel the need to but I use this all the time on tree placements to re design trees into bushes which I find perfect and can cover up all them empty parts of your park easily if you want to go for that U.k looking park style. Flat rides, there is a couple at the moment which don't have animation until phase 2 but the models of them so far just look stunning. I really am looking forward to phase 2 of this game though as coaster building and flat ride animation will be introduced to the game and if the coaster building is as simple as the other elements have been for me then that is also a bonus. Early Access Review

Well I have played Theme Park Studio for around 9 hours now and I feel I am in a better position to review the title. (a better position than a lot of people who have reviewed with under 1 hour of play time).

That's the thing you see, TPS needs time. Time for you to scrape away the deep layers that reveal itself over hours of play and time for Pantera to release more of the game to us like the ride and coaster modules.

When I first had a go at sketchup I blasted it for being nonsensical and useless but then I came back to it and persevered and discovered that it was actually a very powerful design tool. TPS is the same in that the more you put in, the more you get out.

The UI seems logical and practical enabling me to feel familiar with all the buttons within half an hour or so. The camera is a bit awkward but I understand this is being worked on as we speak.

Laying paths takes a bit of getting used to and is the thing I struggled with most initially. I was frustrated that paths were taking so long to learn and lay but then I realised that actually the reason for this is because you are given so many different ways to manipulate and dress them, it creates almost limitless possibilities and once you get to grips with it, the time invested in tweaking the paths really pays off.

The graphics are astounding. I have taken some screenshots that look almost like photos. You can zoom into individual leafs on a tree if you really want to. If you want to alter the shadows and water reflection properties, go right ahead.
After investing some time into TPS you realise that you have an open access pass to do whatever you damn well like and I haven't even began to play around with the texture editor or started importing my own customer models yet. And all the while, with all these options, it does not feel like you are writing your own computer game.


Some have voiced concerns that without a money aspect to the game, there is little to do in TPS but those people are missing the whole point. The payoff is yet to be realised. If you would like to design a theme park and then walk around the curvy streets looking up at the rides spinning and the coasters zooming by amongst the hustle and bustle of a theme park atmosphere then this *will* appeal to you. Coasters, flat rides, ambient sounds and people have not made it into the game yet so we have to imagine them all for now while we go through the early access process but even at this early stage, Theme Park Studio already presents itself as a competent design tool that will emerge into a comprehensive and immersive theme park experience.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Almost ten years after no alternative option to RollerCoasterTycoon 3, Pantera have stepped up to bring us Theme Park Studio, a game that from screen shots and trailers promises to be intuitive in every sense of the word and a worthy successor to the king of theme park simulation franchises.

To those of you who felt constrained and restricted in other rollercoaster and theme park game franchises, Theme Park Studio is the game to set you free from these virtual chains. The placement of objects, structures, rides and paths is far more open and varied than the clunky placement of RCT3, which somewhat won over our hearts with its cartoony graphics that seemed like a step backwards from its predecessors. Theme Park Studio however benefits from somewhat realistic graphics [depending on the textures the user decides to unleash]. There are one or two rough areas regarding the graphics thus far, but when the game is fully released and every function becomes available, the landscapes users will be able to create will inevitably look gorgeous and will be leagues ahead of any other franchise.

Some of the exclusive modules such as the coaster train designer permit even more creativity from users, promising each park, ride and attraction will be totally unique. One of the most desirable features users have wished for in any theme park franchise to this date is the developer opening their arms to users being able to submit and import custom scenery, rides and attractions easily. With Theme Park Studio, this can be done in a mere few clicks, and downloading CS from the internet will ensure any regular CS users from the RollerCoasterTycoon franchise will be familiar with the location of folder placement.

Whilst the game may feel bare at present, there are still plenty of features to explore and master before the game is fully released. Considering the game is in an early access phase and is set to be released in phases, the results that the community have created thus far are incredible. Replicas of the iconic Main Street USA, a theming element featuring the Incredible Hulk that Universal could only dream of, and an extensive plethora of custom designs already on hand thanks to the extremely varied and creative community. By the time Theme Park Studio is fully released, the community contributed material itself will overwhelm the bog standard library content provided with other franchises. And that's without taking into account the gorgeous features Pantera has promised further down the line.

I hasten to mention that due to the game being in an early access stage, there are negatives to the experience. Users have reported a series of crashes, path designing being far too complicated and users attempting to get to grips with importing custom models. The latter has been solved by the community, who are dedicated to helping and learning from one another. Pantera went out of their way to address the path issues by adding unplanned elements in the game that allows users to add new intersections and transitional pieces to make paths look even better, as well as a detailed video making the process seem as easy as buttering toast. The developers have been dedicated to release a series of updates [including fixing the camera controls which was a much requested feature since day one by the community] and continue to do so on a small basis before the next phase arrives.

If you've been with the theme park and rollercoaster designing franchises since day one, Theme Park Studio is certainly the up and coming development to consider. Whilst the fact that the game is currently only in early access and the remaining features remain yet to be unlocked, the game is promising to derail any other games futile attempts at claiming the throne of theme park and rollercoaster simulators. Whilst the community have had their eyes opened by the prospect of RCT4 being released this year, that will only consist of being 'a PC experience'. Theme Park Studio will be THE PC experience, alongside being an actual video game rather than an internet focused module of course.

If you want the full package then unfortunately, you'll have to wait a little while longer before purchasing. But with that said, the content Pantera are promising to deliver is unrivaled in any shape or form, so I fully suggest if you are a potential buyer that you do so now to familiarise yourself with the current system in place. There is going to be a lot of brand new features down the line which thanks to the intuitive features this game boasts, is going to take a while to learn [that said, the learning curve isn't steep and the process is not arduous]. If you haven't been convinced to purchase this game yet, take a long hard look at the videos and screen shots that users have created thus far. I think they'll undoubtedly win you over.

Danny.

[This is from a purely VR point of view, using DK2.]

tl;dr - It's rollercoasters in VR; that's what it's all about right?

[PROS]
You know those fairground rides that feel that little bit too mechanical, that sometimes go just a little bit too fast and the ones that cause you to have a reality check when you realise you are strapped to a machine?  You know, the really good ones?   I actually felt like I was on one of those. :D

The ride you should defo go on first (the one I am gushing about) looks like a wind turbine, with just one long blade spinning in the middle and a cage at either end of the blade.  In VR it's awesome!  You watch the safety bar go down over you, the platform drops and then you start spinning.  It's convincing.  It's probably the VR experience I have enjoyed the most so far on any game.  It's also quite a buzz standing underneath the ride just watching it.  It's that good!

The game clearly uses physics too.   The trains feel like actual trains and to my laymen's understanding, behave like them.  For instance if a train doesn't quite have the oomph required to get over a crest of a peak, it will rocked back and forth between the slopes it is in until it slows to a stop. The rollercoasters are fully simulated rides and quite convincing in VR!

Apparently the game's main feature isn't VR but the comprehensive set of design tools used to create and share your own rides.  I didn't bother with those but if anyone out there wants me to try out one of their creations, the intenser, the merrier. Bring it on!
[Please please PLEASE! When / if designing for VR, make it convienient for us to get to your rides i.e. please make it easy to get straight to the good stuff! Thanks! ;) ]

Also, constant 75 fps using DK2 on my rig, which is just shy of Oculus' recommended specs too.

[CONS]
Most of these issue are about getting to and from the rides, the rides themself are fab!

Some things will no doubt be fixed, probably by the time you read this, e.g. at the time of writing the movement controls could do with some refining - strafing left and right would be handy etc.  Oh, and you have to do the Oculus Home confirmation screen each time you load a map.

In VR (only concerned with VR!), the fact the game is first and foremost a theme park designer, means at the moment it is a little rough around the edges.    The player can sometimes clip through objects or go to areas they shouldn't.  I have found I try to behave and follow the path like a good Theme Park customer!  Also, the gates can be a little tight for us to get through.

@Developer: Would it be possible to provide a small set of tools for those designing parks for VR?  These could include extra wide gates to make it easy for us in VR to walk through!  Simply doubling the size would resolve this AND double size would mean the fences used for the rollercoasters would still match the train's doors?  :)

TBH, the rides are the main feature and they are awesome!  I can't wait to try this on my mates!

But now there's coasters, and while the interface isn't the best, it's not bad. The only tool I find myself really wanting is for the length slider to allow for longer track pieces. The coaster selection is slim but reasonable for the first release, as is the selection of premade special track pieces. You can however make just about any track shape you want, however it's not easy to get things smooth or symmetrical at this point without using the easy editor.

So if you just want a really good, likely to be great coaster editor, go ahead and grab this game. Just be willing to accept that development on other aspects of the game may be slow or incomplete, but the developer could finish the game as described and any future RCT titles may be in trouble.

****UPDATE****

Finally had time to come back to TPS after a long time away and can testify that most of the points I raised below have been more than adequitely addressed. Sadly I only had time for a quick look and can still see some areas that need further work but there's no doubt that significant progress has been made that leads me to believe that these areas will also in time get attention. Certainly from  the quick look I had I've got little doubt I could now work around any other issues such that they would no longer detract from my enjoyment too much. Based on what I've witnessed I now feel able to recommend this title to those who are interested.

**********

Been keeping an eye on this and No Limits 2 for a while and decided that now that the first 2 stages of designing coasters had been implemented I'd take the plunge as I wanted a tool for designing a wider world than NL2 is really intended for. I can see the potential in it but there are so many frustrating design flaws that I really haven't enjoyed my time with it so far.

First issue is basic camera control. Apparently most users found the original setup really bad so they improved it. If this is the improved version I'd hate to think what the original was like. Okay, it's not terrible but is still very clunky and for a game that involves construction and therefore moving around all the time it should be better. Worst element is that although you can refine the controls there are bugs that mean the game 'forgets' your settings or jumps camera position at times. Bugs in elements like this should have been fixed much earlier in the development lifecycle.

Everything from landscaping to placing track pieces is simple but simply complicated if you want to move from default values. The landscaping tools are an example of where you can set parameters, use the tool, use another tool, move back to the first tool and bam, your settings have reverted to defaults again. Because the settings are hidden behind another button you don't see them, click on the screen and damage your landscape. There's no undo feature so getting back to what you had can be a real pain. Forgetting to include an 'undo' function in a construction game beggers belief!

Place track and ask it to cut into the landscape - instead of cutting to just below the track surface it sometimes decides to eat a much bigger hole out of the ground instead. Try to raise blocks of terrain to resolve - it seamingly raises or lowers as it sees fit based on surrounding tiles! It's frustratingly difficult on occasion to grab a single terrain tile and raise 1 step at a time.

Designing flat rides in game is complicated. Elements like joints etc are in a different group to beams and blocks so you are constantly switching back and forth. Once built you need to add keystone animation. Why not have pre-built ride types where you can just click on individual pieces and edit each bit to create something unique which the game then compiles into an animated finished item using a built in physics engine? The more advanced tools could remain for those that want them. The building blocks are all in game but most people seem to be using an external tool for construction which speaks volumes.

I can see the potential in the title and the fact that they wanted to create a powerful design tool to build your theme park but the same level of power could have been achieved in a far more user friendly way. Yes it's early access so bugs and other issues are understandable but there are fundemantal flaws in design concepts that will always exist. RCT3 was simple but limited in building blocks. Pantera should have 'borrowed' the same basic concept of simplicity in this title but expanded on the blocks and their functionality to increase the power. Click and place is fine but more expansive tools and features just aren't as obvious as they could have been. Sure you could design some beautiful creations in this over time but it's just a question of how often you want to bang your head against the wall in the process

Theme Park Studio is a great design tool that misleadingly advertises as a game.  As with many others before me, I desperately have been on the hunt for a modernized replacement for Roller Coaster Tycoon 3 for over a decade.  Theme Park Studio, while still in beta, seems like it will never acheive the calibur of it's predecessor simply due to the vision leading the game's development.

There are no campaigns or objectives, other than building your dream theme park, and no indication of adding them either.  UI falls flat and dated, showing more hints of a coaster engineer's design tool than ease of use for casual gamers.  Design tools are very intricate and detailed, as they should be, but this makes the casual designer feel very daunted.  For example, learning the pathing tool took several hours and I still feel months of practice is needed to be able to plop down paths quickly when expanding the park.

On positive notes, the realism of coaster design, physics and mechanics are downright amazing.  The coaster building tool is easy to use and easy to get the hang of and very rewarding when a custom coaster is finished.  Transparancy with the development team is appreciated, but I do wish updates would come in quicker.  VR compatibility should prove to be innovative, but I forsee it only being used to showcase new designs from actual coaster manufacturers.

Theme Park Studio seems like a great product to design a coaster and ride it every once and a while, but I doubt I'll ever see micromanagement of peeps, burgers and ticket prices in this game"."

I found many bugs and glitches in the game. It never completely crashed, but it froze many times. I stopped playing it mainly because of that.

5/10 - It's okay, but needs a lot of work. I recommend waiting until it's completely finished.

Early Access Review

I'm a huge fan of the RCT1 gameplay but sometimes I want to create a coaster that looks nice and/or rides nice. Because the latter is not possible in RCT3, I had two choices: NoLimits 2 or Theme Park Studio, I decided to try both.
In my experience, NL2 is far easier to use than TPS and it's also much faster (on my old, terribly slow machine TPS ran at 70% in an empty park, while NL2 still runs at full speed if you ride a coaster without scenery, edit: performance update coming soon). In four hours I'm still far from used to the controls of TPS while I got used to the NL2 controls within one hour, probably less. Good thing is that the path building has been improved (and it really, really needed it).
For my needs, Theme Park Studio is absolutely not the correct program (even though I thought it would be), and thus I won't recommend it.

For reference, this is wanted to do:
-Design crazy track parts (and randomly add the rest of the coaster), usually without any kind of scenery
-Ride great coasters made by others

Both programs have great rides made by others, but where TPS goes more for the simpler just click to build a piece of track (which is easier to get started with), NL2 allows you to easily modify every piece of track into ultimate detail which fits my experimental style of coaster building much better. It took a bit longer for the very first basic coaster (the built in step-by-step tutorial will help), but from then up to the control level I desired was much faster.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When I first heard about this game, I was extremely excited: there was the possibility of a photo-realistic RCT successor with great flat-ride support and integrated scenery. I backed it on Kickstarter and eagerly anticipated the launch date. I then got the game, and was slightly disappointed. I understand that the game is still in Early Access, but there are a few major problems that I need to address:

1. Reliability: one thing you'll remember from all three versions of RCT are their incredible stability. RCT1 and 2 were even built using x86 assembly language, which, despite being old, results in an EXTREMELY crash-proof game (except when using trainers, but that's to be expected). TPS crashes fairly often, which, although being understandable for an early-access game, does not warrant the price tag they are asking.

2. Realism: Ok, so photo-realism is achieved in some cases, but not to the breadth I would have liked. The rides look great, but the included shops seem so cartoony that putting them next to rides is pretty odd looking. The built-in scenery editor is useful for overcoming this, but that comes with what I consider the biggest flaw of the game to be, which is

3. Interface: This program seems almost user-hostile. Yes, there are shortcut keys for everything, along with mouse movements, but the control clunky, options don't make sense, and will sometimes do different things in different situations, and buttons exist that have really no right to exist. One of the best examples is with paths: there's a button to build new paths and a button to continue a path that has already been built. But a button with the same image is also used to bring up the path editor menu. The only thing I liked about the interface was the docking system, when it worked, but there were a few times when the docking menu crashed the game (guess it wasn't finished yet.)

I understand the game is still in Early Access, but I cannot in good faith recommend it, especially when better alternatives exist on Steam

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nHaving backed the game on Kickstarter I was incredibly hyped for the game, following every video and trying to find any evidence of the game. This looked like it could be the best rollercoaster simulator since Roller Coaster Tycoon 3 and looked like it could mix the best of the RCT franchise with the detail of No Limits. However, when the game came out I was severley dissapointed. Of course the features were limited at first, but that was expected. But when features rolled out, my buyers remorse incrased. I had originally written a positive review of this game, optimistic of its future. Now I feel ripped off on spending £20 on this game. If you want realism, go purchase No Limits (haven't used No Limits 2 yet but it looks fantastic) and if you want a more fun central game go play any of the first three Rollercoaster Tycoon Games, Parkitect or Planet Coaster (which again I am yet to play but looks stunning). Theme Park Studio is incredibly buggy, features infuriatingly buggy controls and a coaster builder that will make you punch a hole right through your monitor. Save yourself, don't get this game.
